headline.main: NATIONAL AFFAIRS.; THIRTY-THIRD CONGRESS...Second Session. SENATE. Speech of Mr. Walbridge. EXTRA BILLY AROUSED. SPEECH OF SENATOR SEWARD. Exciting Debate. The Passenger Bill. THE COLLINS LINE. MAIL STEAMER APPROPRIATIONS. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.

docs.lead_paragraph: PASSENGERS IN STEAMSHIPS. Mr. SEWARD, from the Committee on Commerce, asked the consideration of the bill regulating the carriage of passengers in steamships and other vessels. The bill was read twice and put upon its passage, as follows. A BILL TO REGULATE THE CARRIAGE OF PASSENGERS IN STEAMSHIPS AND OTHER VESSELS.

headline.main: How Hygiene is respected in the British Army.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following remarks on a most intersting subject are from the American Medical Monthly for February. They bear the initials of Prof. PEASLEE. During the three inglorious months spent by the allied armies in total inactivity at Scutari, 10,000 men are said to have died of cholera;

headline.main: CAPT. GIBSON'S CASE.; His Explanation of the Bogus Letter.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Honorable Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives. SIR : In my last communication to you, under date of January 27, 1855, I replied to the charge of having abstracted a certain paper from the State Department, preferred by the Secretary of State, in a letter transmitted to Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Asia steamship, at Halifax, brings a week's later news from Europe. The events in Parliament and at Windsor were quite stirring. On Monday Mr. ROKBUCK'S motion of inquiry in the Commons, after speeches from Mr. DISRAELI and others, was adopted by the strong vote against the Government of 305 to 148, and thereupon the Ministry resigned.
